speaker: therapist
text: Hi, I'm Paul.

speaker: client_1
text: Sophie.

speaker: therapist
text: Nice to meet you.  Come on in.

speaker: client_1
text: Here?

speaker: therapist
text: Yes.

speaker: client_1
text: Uh, do you need any help with the --

speaker: therapist
text: No, it's okay.  Okay.

speaker: client_1
text: Anna Colden recommended that I talk to you.

speaker: therapist
text: Anna Colden?

speaker: client_1
text: She's my lawyer.  She heard about you from a friend of yours.  I mean, a friend of hers, not a friend of yours.  From a patient of yours who is a friend of hers.  Sorry.

speaker: therapist
text: Hmm.  So, Anna Colden recommended you through a patient of mine.  Do you know, do you know his name?

speaker: client_1
text: I don't know.

speaker: therapist
text: So what, what did Anna recommend me for?

speaker: client_1
text: After my accident -- I told you on the phone about the accident.

speaker: therapist
text: Yes.

speaker: client_1
text: They told me that I need the opinion of a psychiatrist, because the insurance company of the car that hit me has a problem with my injuries, or, something like that.  So, that's why I'm here.  I'm here for your professional opinion, not for... Not for... not for therapy.

speaker: therapist
text: So let's see if I'm, uh -- if I'm getting this right.  Are you... suing the insurance company of the person who hit you?

speaker: client_1
text: No, their insurance company had me talk to a social worker.  She started asking me all sorts of annoying questions.  She was really annoying, so I refused to talk to her.  She started talking to me like she knew me or something, so, I refused to talk.  And, that didn't go over so well, so, my mother said, it would be better if I came here to talk to you.

speaker: therapist
text: And, that didn't go over so well, so, my mother said, it would be better if I came here to talk to you.

speaker: therapist
text: Okay.  So what happened at the accident that requires a... a psychiatric opinion?

speaker: client_1
text: I really don't remember what happened.

speaker: therapist
text: I was on my bicycle, and a car ran into me, and I don't remember what happened next.  What did they tell you afterwards?

speaker: client_1
text: That I flew my bike right into the street.

speaker: therapist
text: You're... you're laughing at that.  What that sounds like, "flying straight into the street"?

speaker: client_1
text: Because... it reminds me of something, about two years ago.  A friend of mine, he... took me out on this motorbike, and he stopped to get something at a convenience store.  Anyway, I was really bored, so, I pretended that I knew how to drive it.  You know, you put your hands on the handlebars and you go like this. Well, it was one of those monster bikes. Just by turning the handle a little it just flies. So, suddenly I'm like zoom, and it takes off. My head whips back like this. And when I look back down I realize that I'm riding into the street. Totally crashed into a car. Oh. There was this... old woman standing nearby, and she saw all this. "I saw her, she did it on purpose. She tried to kill herself. She tried to kill herself." That's what -- that's what she was yelling?

speaker: therapist
text: Yeah, she was like a crazy woman.

speaker: client_1
text: Oh.  Of course, it couldn't have been that funny when it happened, I'm sure.  No, not really.  I wanted to kill her.  I was just lying there. I couldn't move. I couldn't do anything. I wanted to yell, "Shut up, you... you idiot! Why are you screaming?" You know, but I couldn't speak. It's like... this feeling... when somebody says something about you and you can't defend yourself. It's totally unfair. Like that... social worker you were talking about.

speaker: therapist
text: What -- what does she have to do with it?

speaker: client_1
text: Well, didn't you feel that she was speaking for you?

speaker: therapist
text: Yeah, but I could have said something. I just didn't want to.

speaker: client_1
text: Well, didn’t you feel that she was speaking for you?

speaker: client_1
text: Yeah, but I could have said something. I just didn’t want to.

speaker: therapist
text: So, tell me a little bit more about this, uh—this accident.

speaker: therapist
text: It’s on that report. Where did it happen?

speaker: client_1
text: In a gas station on Madison near the gym where I train.

speaker: therapist
text: So you were on the way to the gym?

speaker: client_1
text: I don’t know. I told you I don’t remember anything.

speaker: therapist
text: Do you feel… comfortable… talking about yourself, Sophie?

speaker: client_1
text: No.

speaker: client_1
text: My name is Sophie. I’m 16 years old.

speaker: client_1
text: I’ve been a gymnast since the age of six and a half. I was U.S. Junior champion at the age of 12.

speaker: therapist
text: I’m kind of like… an Olympic hopeful.

speaker: therapist
text: Wow! That’s really impressive. Congratulations.

speaker: client_1
text: Thank you.

speaker: therapist
text: So, how is life in general?

speaker: client_1
text: I, I, I just don’t have the energy for “This Is Your Life” right now.

speaker: therapist
text: “This Is Your Life”? What do you mean?

speaker: therapist
text: It's okay. Some of the people on it are so old.

speaker: client_1
text: Why do you think they put old people on that?

speaker: therapist
text: I don't know.

speaker: therapist
text: Because they have nothing better to do. They're retired and they're dying off fast, so, they put them on the show before it's too late.

speaker: client_1
text: So, do you think you can help me with this professional opinion or not?

speaker: therapist
text: Well, it's not that simple, Sophie.

speaker: client_1
text: Why not?
